title: Name ownership is an absolute right
content: ENS governance will not enact any change that infringes on the rights of ENS users to retain names they own, or unfairly discriminate against name owners’ ability to renew, transfer, or otherwise use their names.
positiveExample: ENS governance may enact a change affecting the registration or renewal costs of all names based on transparent criteria such as length, as long as it pursues a goal outlined in this constitution.
negativeExample: ENS governance must not enact a change increasing or reducing the renewal costs of a list of existing ENS names, as this would unfairly benefit or penalise a handpicked group.

title: Registration fees exist as an incentive mechanism
content: The primary purpose of registration fees is as an incentive mechanism, to regulate the registration, renewal, and expiry of ENS names, and prevent the namespace becoming overwhelmed with speculatively registered names. A secondary goal is to provide enough revenue to the DAO to fund ongoing development and improvement of ENS. ENS governance will not enact any fee other than for these purposes.
positiveExample: Example: ENS governance may increase the price of name registrations in order to address excessive speculative registrations induced by a price that is set too low, or because the current price is insufficient to fund ongoing ENS operations at a reasonable level.
negativeExample: Example: ENS governance must not enact a change imposing a fee for claiming DNS domains inside ENS, because such a fee would be purely an income generating measure and not an incentive mechanism.

title: Income funds ENS and other public goods
content:
Any income generated to the ENS treasury is to be used first of all to ensure the long-term viability of ENS, and to fund continuing development and improvement of the ENS system. Funds that are not reasonably required to achieve this goal may be used to fund other public goods as ENS governance sees fit.

ENS governance will not allocate funds to a team or individual who does not commit to uphold the same principles outlined in this constitution in their use of the allocated funds.
positiveExample: ENS governance may offer grant funding for a public good unrelated to ENS or Ethereum, so long as doing so does not affect the long-term viability of ENS.
negativeExample: ENS governance must not use the funds to pay out a dividend to holders of ENS governance tokens.

title: ENS Integrates with the global namespace
content: In order to facilitate making the most widely usable naming system, ENS aims to integrate with the legacy DNS naming system to the greatest extent possible without sacrificing decentralization of ENS. ENS governance will not enact changes that compromise ENS’s ability to do this.
positiveExample: ENS governance should grant control of a top-level domain to its owner in the DNS system on request.
negativeExample: ENS governance must not create new top-level domains unless those domains have been granted to ENS by a DNS authority, or there is no chance of those domains colliding with a DNS-issued top-level domain of the same name.
